name: myrica-caroliniensis
distribution: Primarily in coastal plains of SE US
wildlife-value: It provides excellent winter and extreme weather coverage.  It is a host plant for the Red-banded Hairstreak butterfly. Its fruits are eaten by birds, especially yellow-rumped warblers (which are very efficient at digesting the waxy fruits), in the fall and winter.
edibility: Leaves can be used like bay leaves to flavor soups, stews, etc.
light: Dappled Sunlight (Shade through upper canopy all day)
Full sun (6 or more hours of direct sunlight a day)
Partial Shade (Direct sunlight only part of the day, 2-6 hours)
fruit-description: Small green to blue-white to grey dry waxy globose fruit that does not split open.  Fruits are on female plants only and appear from late summer to early fall.
flower-description: Small male and female slim cylindrical flowers appear late spring to early summer.
leaf-description: Waxy, leathery, simple alternate  dark green leaves with toothed margins.  Blades are 1-3 inches long and 1/4- 1 inch wide and have resinous glands on the underside.
bark-description: Thin, smooth and white to gray/brown.
stem-description: Three or more scales overlap like shingles, hairy stems
uses: The waxy coating on the fruits has been used in candle making.
